g.text: that these minerals decompose into their component silicates and carbonates above 4 GPa and
the other hand, experimental studies at low pressures suggest that spurrite and tilleyite have a field of stability
. It is then fundamental to invest in a more detailed knowledge of these compounds
at pressures and temperatures of deep subduction regions, since these silicate-carbonate minerals might be con-
stituents of “cold” slabs. In this regard, it is important to attain an accurate description of the crystal structures
and physical properties of these materials at high pressures and temperatures. The compressibility and phase
stability of spurrite up to 27 GPa and 700 K have been recently reported
which suggests that the presence of carbonate [CO
] units gives stability to the tetrahedral [SiO
group, holding up the formation of phases based on octahedral [SiO
] units. What occurs to tilleyite with a similar
configuration remains unknown calling for further investigations.
Tilleyite is a naturally-occurring calcium silicate-carbonate mineral that conforms well with the chemical
, but some minor substitution of other elements such as Al, Mg or F could occur
It is therefore the most carbonated compound of the calcium silicate-carbonate family. The existence of this
mineral was firstly reported by Larsen and Durham in 1933 from contact altered limestones at Crestmore quar-
. The monoclinic crystal structure of tilleyite was firstly determined by Smith
. The structure contains the following atom-centered oxygen
polyhedra with different coordination spheres for Ca atoms (20% are octahedrally coordinated, 60% are forming
7-fold-coordinated capped octahedra and 20% are forming distorted cubes). It is envisaged that the flexibility
of the bridging Si–O–Si dihedral angle of the disilicate group upon compression could lead to an increase of the
coordination number of the Ca atoms and the transition to a denser phase.
Here we present, in contrast to spurrite counterpart, the formation of a novel silicate-carbonate phase after
compressing tilleyite above 8 GPa. The high-pressure polymorph is characterized
(XRD) and Raman spectroscopy. DFT calculations confirm that the new phase is thermodynamically more stable
at these conditions. We also found evidence for a second dense silicate-carbonate polymorph above 21 GPa. The
initial tilleyite structure is recovered after pressure is quenched.
phase stability and determination of a high-pressure phase.
urements on tilleyite were performed under compression. The initial sample can be described with a monoclinic
4), which are in excellent agreement with previously reported cell dimensions of other
Crestmore specimens (once expressed in the same crystallographic setting). The structure is depicted in Fig.
and the atomic coordinates of the 22 independent atoms within the unit cell at ambient conditions are collected
of the Supplementary Information, SI (to be compared with literature data of Table
ical features of the structure are the same as previously determined, but a brief summary is needed to analyze
along the three unitcell axes. Blue, light gray, light green and red spheres represent C, Si, Ca and O atoms,
respectively. Cell edges are depicted as solid black lines. Red solid lines on post-tilleyite projections demarcate
the location of tilleyite unitcell contents, for the sake of comparison between structures.
